text:
Caver injured in fall at Harwoods Hole in Abel Tasman National Park Last updated 15:05, February 28 2017 JOHN 'OZ' PATTERSON 
A caver looks like a tiny spider as he descends into Harwoods Hole in 1993. 
At least one caver has been injured after a fall at Harwoods Hole, the deepest vertical shaft in New Zealand. 
It is understood that others are with the injured climber at the bottom of the hole. 
Senior Sergeant Blair Hall from Nelson police said emergency services were responding to a report of a caving accident at the hole on top of Takaka Hill, northwest of Nelson. SIMON MANEY 
The 183m abseil descent into Harwoods Hole is for experienced cavers only. 
In a statement, police said the alarm was raised by a group in the area and a helicopter had been sent to the scene. 
READ MORE: * Rescued cavers 'ill-equipped, inexperienced' 
Cave rescue specialists, the Fire Service and St John Ambulance were also involved. 
St John Ambulance crew member Anne-Maree Harris said a rescue crew was trying to gain access to the cave at the moment. 
Robin Reeve, of New Zealand Land Search and Rescue, said LandSAR was setting up a repeater to enable communications between the SAR base at Motueka and rescuers at the remote site which has limited coverage. 
Reeve said he understood local cavers had also been called to assist in the rescue operation. 
Harwoods Hole is a 176-metre deep sinkhole. It drops to an underground river that emerges below and flows into Gorge Creek and then into the Takaka River. Ad Feedback 
Several scenes from Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy were filmed in the complex of caves at the bottom of the shaft. 
Situated in a remote part of Takaka Hill in Golden Bay with little to no cellphone reception, Harwoods Hole is a 45-minute walk from the Canaan car park, through distinctive limestone rock formations.â€‹
